title: Portrait reveals love triangle involving Van Dyke and Rubens, Cambridge academic claims
text:
For almost 400 years it has been believed that a portrait of the wife of the virtuoso artist Peter Paul Rubens, painted by his mentee the younger Anthony Van Dyck, was a gift of friendship.

The reality, according to one Cambridge academic, is that in may in fact indicate a betrayal between two of the world’s greatest Flemish Baroque artists.

Cambridge academic Dr John Harvey has said he believes the portrait could allude to a sordid affair between the man Rubens sculpted into a great and his own wife.

The painting, titled Portrait of Isabella Brant is believed to have been created in 1621, supposedly to honour Rubens.

But a Cambridge academic has cast a new light on the nature of artwork, claiming that Van Dyck may have left clues of an adulterous romance with Rubens' wife, Brant.

Cambridge academic Dr John Harvey began to investigate the story of the image while researching his forthcoming novel Pax, which reimagines episodes from Rubens' life.

The portrait was produced 12 years after Brant married Rubens and is now housed in the National Gallery of Art in Washington DC.

There it is described as being a parting gift from Van Dyck to his mentor, as he left for an extended stay in Italy.
